bestBHT.bht: The word used here does not indicate contempt but rather familiarity, referring to tame dogs that would be found running around a family meal. The woman skillfully used this sense of familiarity to demonstrate her faith and convince the disciples that it was appropriate for her to receive blessings. This distinction between Jews and Gentiles was later removed with the spread of the Gospel. Jesus was testing the woman's faith and warning of impending judgment for the Jews who rejected the offered salvation.

Henry Alford: No contempt is indicated by the diminutive, still less any allusion to the daughter of the woman.
The word is commonly used of tame dogs, as diminutives frequently express familiarity.
Marvin Vincent: Children's [των τεκνων]...he spoke honorably of them to those without.
Dogs [κυναριοις]...The picture is of a family meal, with the pet house-dogs running round the table.
Their masters. The children are the masters of the little dogs.
John Calvin: But this must be restricted to that time when it was in Judea only that men called on God; for, since the Gentiles were admitted to partake of the same salvations—which took place when Christ diffused everywhere the light of his Gospel—the distinction was removed, and those who were formerly dogs are now reckoned among the children."
The pride of the flesh must fall down when we learn that by nature we are dogs.

His chief design was to make trial of the woman’s faith, but he also pointed out the dreadful vengeance that would overtake the Jews, who rejected an inestimable benefit which was freely offered to them, and which they refused to those who sought it with warmth and earnestness.
Philip Schaff: It calls forth the woman’s faith, and convinces the disciples that it is ‘proper’ to bless this heathen woman.
All present understood this as referring to the blessings provided for the Jews.
Household dogs are meant; a sense the woman skillfully used.
John Gill: By 'the children', are meant the Jews...being under the more peculiar care and notice of God.
By 'the bread'; which belonged to them, is meant the external ministry of the word, and the miracles of Christ.
By 'the dogs' are designed the Gentiles, so called by the Jews in a way of contempt, because of their ignorance, idolatry, and impurity.

bhtAttempts.bht: The word used for dogs in Matthew 15:26 does not indicate any contempt, but rather familiarity. It refers to tame dogs, like the ones that would run around a family meal. The woman skillfully used this sense of familiarity to demonstrate her faith and convince the disciples that it was appropriate for her to receive blessings. While at that time the distinction between Jews and Gentiles still existed, with the Jews being referred to as the children and the Gentiles as the dogs, later on this distinction was removed with the spread of the Gospel. Jesus was not only testing the woman's faith, but also warning of the judgment that awaited the Jews who rejected the salvation freely offered to them.

While at that time the distinction between Jews and Gentiles still existed, this distinction was later removed with the spread of the Gospel. Jesus was testing the woman's faith and warning of the judgment that awaited the Jews who rejected the salvation freely offered to them.

The woman skillfully used this sense of familiarity to demonstrate her faith and convince the disciples that it was appropriate for her to receive blessings. This distinction between Jews and Gentiles was later removed with the spread of the Gospel. The word used in this verse does not indicate contempt, but rather familiarity. It refers to tame dogs, like those that would be found running around a family meal. The woman skillfully used this familiarity to demonstrate her faith and convince the disciples that she too should receive blessings. While the distinction between Jews and Gentiles existed at that time, it was later removed through the spread of the Gospel. Jesus was testing the woman's faith and warning of the judgment that awaited the Jews who rejected the offered salvation.

The term dogs used in this passage does not imply contempt but rather familiarity and refers to tame household dogs. The woman shrewdly used this sense of familiarity to display her faith and convince the disciples of her worthiness to receive blessings. Although there was a distinction between Jews and Gentiles at that time, this division was later abolished by the spread of the Gospel. Jesus' intention was to test the woman's faith while also warning the Jews of the impending judgment for rejecting the salvation offered to them.
